safeFields.trailText: Over-by-over report: There's surely no way back for England at Headingley. Is there? Follow the final day now
safeFields.headline: England v Sri Lanka: second Test – live!
safeFields.body:
12.14pm BST

Here come the covers. And on reflection, this might be better for Sri Lanka than England. It's not serious enough to threaten play for too long, there are plenty of overs to be told and there's plenty of scope to extend the day. And England were defending well, Root and Ali finding decent rhythm, even if it was more bossa nova than happy hardcore. Now, they'll need to refocus and re-establish when play resumes.

12.12pm BST

THE UMPIRES CONVENE IN THE MIDDLE!

AND OFF THEY GO!

12.11pm BST

44th over: England 83-5 (Root 9, Ali 22)

Eranga produces a lovely full-lengther, close enough to off stump to worry Moeen. But his judgement is sound, and he leaves it, while the umpires appear to be assessing the light - a large and cloud cloud is stretching out over the middle, and there are no lights. Them, just as Bumble is advising against the deployment of a bouncer, Eranga persuades one to lift, Moeen doing well to sway out of the way. Maiden.

12.07pm BST

43rd over: England 83-5 (Root 9, Ali 22)

Don Anurasiri can relax - Herath is thanked, Mathews introducing himself to the attack, though it turns out they're already well acquainted with him. And what's this? It's raining! But only lightly, and with no hint of anything more sub-sub-sub-substantial. Meanwhile, Mathews almost induces a shot from Moeen, who removes his bat outside off-stump at the last moment, before turning a single away on the leg side form the final ball.

"For me the Cook issue is simple," emails Ian Truman. we need his batting back, his captaincy ability could be replaced by a robot "Wade by a Japanese car manufacturer, but his batting can’t be so easily replaced. If only for Cook the person, let him go back to enjoying the game again."

I'd agree with that. It's not just that he's failing as a captain, more that he doesn't look likely to succeed, nor does he appear to believe that he will.

Updated at 12.09pm BST

12.01pm BST

42nd over: England 82-5 (Root 9, Ali 21)

Eranga tempts Moeen by mistake, firing one down leg side that he follows, but misses with his glance. Then, after more defending, a single - England are doing their best to ensure that they're not tempted by the illusory prospect of victory - and drinks.

"I'm not so bothered about England losing", says Alfred Moore. "What's really depressing is the way they're going about it. That's why we're talking about Cook's captaincy. For all the new faces, it's the same old strategy and 'brand' (to use a Vaughnism) of cricket: pack the top order with passive, nuggety nudgers, slowly grind out big scores, and then hope that pack of fairly good seam bowlers hit the right areas. Even if they were winning I'd be depressed."

That's a little harsh. Moeen, Bell and Root aren't that, and Robson's form has demanded inclusion. I also think it's harsh on the bowlers, but agree that the fields, lines and lengths could be more attacking.

11.57am BST

41st over: England 81-5 (Root 9, Ali 20)

A briefly vocal appeal, when Herath turns one into Root and contracts pad - but via inside edge, as is quickly accepted.

Meanwhile, Colum Farrelly has a lesson for us all: "Well, it is not an anecdote of hilarity, but perhaps we could be happy that after 50 minutes play, no one is out?"

11.54am BST

40th over: England 81-5 (Root 9, Ali 20)

Eranga is not looking especially threatening, so, paradoxically, looks especially threatening - Ali plays out a maiden. Mentioned this the other day, but a wine company is offering consumers the chance to win a net with members of the England team - or, put another way, pain, humiliation, or both. Has anyone ever won anything worse? My entry: a Panini '86 sticker album, in winter '87.

Talking og maidens, here's Ravi Nair confiding in us: "You asked for our worst defeat-from-the-jaws-of-victory stories so maybe this'll make you feel better. "18 or 20 years ago, company annual conference, and an absolutely lovely lass says she really needs to turn in, so I escort her to her room and, when she smiles at me from the door, I decide to be all gentlemanly, ask her to have a nice night, and shut the door to go downstairs for more drinkies. Three years later, feeling confiding at her boyfriend's barbecue, she tells me 'that was the worst knock-back of my life'. Hah! How about how stupid and incompetent at reading the signs I felt? Nothing Cook has done in the last six months can compare. Take heart Alastair!"

This is an inversion of the OBO norm if ever there was one. It must be a sign.

11.49am BST

39th over: England 81-5 (Root 9, Ali 20)

The batsmen meet and exchange a "safe", or a "fist-bump" as we must now call it, the redundant decadence of modern society encapsulated right there. Moeen is looking confident now,striding down the track to absorb the spin and adding a two to backward point followed by a single nurdled by silly point. Root is still struggling to get off strike, perhaps an even more significant weakness than his front foot issue.

11.45am BST

38th over: England 78-5 (Root 9, Ali 17)

Eranga replaces Prasad, who can't find the magic of last night - he might never, in all his life. "If you feel the need to respond to the people on the hill, it's time to go", says Russell Arnold of Cook - and, for what it's worth, I don't agree. That's a symptom, and one easily alleviated, not the cause. He then, though, points out that Jayawardene binned the captaincy to save his batting, which makes more sense.

Anyway, this is all becoming rather morbid, so if anyone can furnish us with an anecdote of hilarity, please, that'd help save the world.

11.41am BST

37th over: England 76-5 (Root 9, Ali 16)

Brief alarm when Moeen presses forward and misses, taking one on the pad - there's a slip, a leg slip, a short leg and silly point. But, looking vulnerable, he manages to slice one away on the leg side and they run one.

"You finished day 1's coverage with an REM lyric", emails Smylers. "I happened to search for it, and was somewhat surprised to discover that your words about Alistair Cook had somehow found themselves into another publications' articles about Obama's foreign policy, among others. Maybe the OBO is always 'syndicated' in this bizarre way, but thought I'd let you know in case you hadn't seen it before."

Obama could learn much from the pooled misery and pressure of existing that's exemplified by the OBO - I can see exactly how that might happen.

Updated at 11.45am BST

11.37am BST

36th over: England 75-5 (Root 9, Ali 15)

Root has looked fairly solid this morning, affecting confidence only occasionally belied by rashness. He plays this over from Prasad comfortably, easily avoiding a bouncer and ignoring that which is wide like a stoic Scotsman. Second maiden in a row.

11.33am BST

35th over: England 75-5 (Root 9, Ali 15)

A quiet over, so:

"I'm all for reasoned debate," retorst Gary Naylor, "and there is a reasoned debate to be had, but it wouldn't have reached this fever pitch in the past about a captain with that record, part-way through a Test, a week after failing to win one because his second slip was half a yard too deep. I was all for dropping Cook after his last run of dodgy batting just before the 2010-11 Ashes - how did he do in that series?"

Well, it did in 1989, but I don't think the issue here is what happened last week. He presided over the worst winter in history, and in the period, his own form has plummeted. In 2010-11, the team was settled, and his form could be worn. Now, the team needs it more importantly than it needs to hope it might suddenly improve along with his captaincy.

11.30am BST

34th over: England 75-5 (Root 9, Ali 15)

Width for Root, and he paddles away on the off-side for a single. Then, a lovely shot from Moeen, full face kissing cork to earn four down the ground; his positivity is deeply endearing, and just what this team needs. Let's hope he can back it up with what the Talmud calls tachlis.

"It wasn’t David Moyes fault that the team wouldn’t play for him," says Jordan Wagner. "That being said the team aren’t playing for Alistair. I think the captaincy might well be taken from him but I wouldn’t want anyone else at the top of the order. It will come good eventually… as they say form is temporary…"

I disagree re Moyes, for what it's worth - he alienated and failed to inspire the players, precisely his job. I don't think that's Cook's problem - more his own form, and suspect decision-making.

11.25am BST

33rd over: England 69-5 (Root 8, Ali 10)

I remember England playing Sri Lanka at Lord's in 1991, and Don Anurasiri bowling something like 65,092 overs unchanged - it looks like Herath is set for that kind of day today. This is a quieter over, so he tosses up its final delivery, turned towards midwicket by Root, and they shuffle a single.

Updated at 11.33am BST

11.22am BST

32nd over: England 68-5 (Root 7, Ali 10)

Moeen sees a wide one, and, keen to attack, cuts hard and high past gully for four. Then, a half-volley that he attempts to drive and instead deflects past a misfield for four more.

11.20am BST

31st over: England 60-5 (Root 7, Ali 2)

Moeen heaves at Herath - quite where he was planning the ball to go is unclear. Looked to me like a drive, looked to Strauss like a slog-sweep, so we'l go with me him. It ends up squirting to midwicket, and they run one, as a bloke wanders into the commentary box, much to Bumble's bemusement. Can he bat?

"I'm with Gary Naylor on this one", emails Ravi Nair. "Reasoned criticism of Cook is fair enough, but he has a vastly inexperienced team at his disposal (and no matter what one may think of the absence of the Whistler, Cook can hardly be held responsible for the loss of Trott, Swann, Tremlett and Finn), so why not give him until the end of the Summer?"

I'd not mind either way, but my principal concern is Cook's batting. In any event, can you see things improving, or getting worse? There comes a time, when, much as you'd like not to, you need to act because things have become so bad- it happened with David Moyes at Manchester United, for example.

Updated at 11.21am BST

11.14am BST

30th over: England 59-5 (Root 7, Ali 1)

Ali nudges himself off the mark, down into the off-side, bringing Root on strike - his ability to rotate the aforementioned, a glaring weakness thus far, will be crucial today. He plays out four dots.

11.10am BST

29th over: England 58-5 (Root 7, Ali 0)

Gosh, this is difficult to watch - Root does not, at this early stage, appear to have a plan against Herath, beyond survival. He takes one on the pad that's not far off - ah, inside edge - and then begins an absurd run off the final ball, scurrying back when the ridiculousness dawns on him.

Updated at 11.12am BST

11.08am BST

28th over: England 58-5 (Root 7, Ali 0)

It's Prasad from the other end, and, despite the snark regarding his avant-garde Test record, he bowled superbly yesterday. Root accidentally squirts his first ball away on the leg side for England's first run of the morning; just the 292 to go. Mathews responds by putting in a third slip, and he Prasad illustrates the purpose, bowling a full, drivable ball, that Moeen ignores, then another, slightly closer to the stumps. And, with the fifth delivery, comes the inevitable play and miss - that was close.

"Cook averages over 44 with the bat as captain and, even if he loses this match,
has won more Tests than he has lost or drawn", reckons Gary Naylor. "I know we're in a 24/7 news cycle fuelled by journalists monitoring Twitter outrage, but isn't the time to judge him at the end of the summer. Or is that slot already taken by the Bell-baiters
for when he has taken over and failed?"

His average as captain is not the most crucial piece of information when he and the team are in such an alarming slump. I also wouldn't conflate nor demean fair, reasoned and concerned debate with nebulous "Twitter outrage".



11.01am BST

27th over: England 57-5 (Root 6, Ali 0)

Herath is immediately into the rough outside Moeen's off-stump, the third delivery straighter than the first two, and the fourth simply going straight on, beating the bat. Beautifully bowled.

10.59am BST

Herath will finish his over...

10.59am BST

The players are coming out. Jeremy Yapp is thinking numbers: "In a match of 1,136 runs so far, with 35 wickets fallen, there have been nine – nine! – ducks, five of them golden. That’s a lot, right?"

Yes, it's a lot - not sure I can recall as many golden.

10.57am BST

A game: what's the finest mess you've made of a potentially advantageous circumstance?

10.56am BST

"I will forgive Cook many of his failings", posits the magnanimous Ravi Nair, "if he makes up for not playing Ali first thing yesterday, by not playing him first thing today either. How's that for funky captaincy?"

Tangentially, given Sri Lanka's matchwinning spinner, and England's no matchwinning spinner, ought Cook to have batted first?

10.54am BST

"Might I suggest that today is an opportunity", suggests Robert Wilson. "A moment for English cricket fans to do what they do with such matchless wit and poise - lose really badly. I'm serious. Has there ever been a finer set of human beings than the followers of England cricket in the '90s (and quite a lot of the eighties)? It's nothing so shallow as masochistic relish, they don't enjoy having their arses handed to them. It's a rueful acknowledgement of human frailty and opposition talent - eg. all the top-grade Matthews-love yesterday. It brings out the best in them. Tell me that's not admirable.
If the football fans were like that, Emile Heskey would be an almost sacred figure and people would still be weeping about Peter Beardsley. Not sure about Gerrard though."

I'm afraid success has ruined us.

10.47am BST

Which isn't to say that it's all Cook's fault. It's not been (only) him dropping catches, it's not been (only) him giving his wicket away, and it's not been him bowling wide and short. His players need acquainting with various truths, forthwith.

10.44am BST

And the contrast with Angelo Mathews is all too stark. Tough, purposeful, and all of that - but, most significantly, inspired by the role and inspiring others through that inspiration.

10.30am BST

Preamble

One of sport's significant beauties is its ability to isolate the individual in a manner rarely seen in real life – except that for those individuals, it is real life. Lucky us, and, for the most part, lucky them.

But sometimes, things become too much, the pleasure in the show overidden by the uncomfortable tragedy of failure. Roughly, this is where we are with Alastair Cook.

A year ago, he wasn't simply an outstanding batsman but an epochal, barely believable phenomenon. Now, he is the subject either of ridicule, or a gentle, considered criticism that earnestly and tacitly acknowledges his decency, sympathising with the speed and intensity of his fall – which in some ways, is even worse.

And there is no sporting arena less forgiving than Test cricket. On the pitch and on camera for five days, nuances, airtime and erudite analysts make it impossible to obscure errors, the role of captain is more pronounced that in any sport. So it's not remotely tricky to enumerate yesterday's errors: allowing Jayawardene and Mathews - Jayawardene and Mathews – to play themselves in, not bowling Moeen with the old ball, not altering his new ball attack when it wasn't working, giving away free runs, not going at Mathews, setting defensive fields, and all the rest.

But even in Test cricket, the crucial aspect of captaincy is the same as in anything else: consistent excellence in your principal role. Currently, Cook is not worth his place in the team; were he not captain, he might already have been dropped, and relinquishing it might be the only way he can recover his form. Were Cook batting well, England would most likely win this match, his dismissal yesterday even more telling than one caused by a technical deficiency; the shot that caused him to drag on evidenced an impatient and frazzled man, precisely what he is not, but now is.

Whether he remains in his position after today remains to be seen. The ECB cannot intervene, given the extraordinary backing they gave him, but his confidence in his own ability to do the job is not obvious. A happy, equilibrious Cook does not use a press conference to argue with Shane Warne, remaining secure in the knowledge that imminent success will resolve things for him.

Alternatively, Joe Root and Moeen Ali knock off the runs, England clinch the series sometime after tea, Cook relaxes, stops feeling for the ball outside off-stump and turning catches behind the wicket on the leg-side, punishes India, and we and he laugh at what nearly was.

Updated at 10.37am BST
safeFields.standfirst:
• Second Test updates from the final day's play at Headingley
• England start day five on 57-5, chasing 350 to win
• And you can email daniel.harris.casual@theguardian.com

safeFields.trailText: Rolling report: Keep up with all the latest news and updates from all the teams in Brazil
safeFields.headline: World Cup 2014: day 13 – live!
safeFields.body:
12.01pm BST

Doyle at your service. Let me kick off my tenure of this here live blog with what I, Jimmy Armfield and Graham Taylor like to call a “greeting”. Hello, as we like to say. And now let's look forward a little to the big match of the day, which, of course, England are not involving, Roy Hodgson having contrived to finish the Group of Death with a dead rubber. So then, Italy v Uruguay for a place in the last 16: you have to say that's magnificent.

The Italian media have worked themselves up into a state of high agitation, with headlines this morning such as “No more Kidding Around” and “No, We Must Not Return Home!”. TuttoSport reckon that “today is all about heart and character, we no longer have any alibi”, a theme that even manager Cesare Prandelli seems happy to take up, reminding his players that “We must remember that we are fighting for the motherland – we are the only ones representing Italy here.” As for Uruguay, thanks to their wonderful garra charrua, they never need to be reminded to fight. “Three million of us are behind our team!” trumpets La Republica, who hail “the national team's exemplary behaviour so far, both individually and collectively.” Naturally they were saying exactly the same thing after the defeat to Costa Rica.

11.44am BST

That's it from me. With day breaking and journalists waking up all over Brazil, I'm going to hand you over to Paul Doyle, who will be scouring the worldwide web to bring you news as they report it.

11.41am BST

Yaya Touré attacks Manchester City again

In the wake of his younger brother Ibrahim's death from cancer last week, Yaya Touré has used his column in France Football to launch another scathing attack on Manchester City, who he claims refused to allow him time off to spend time with his sibling in the wake of their title win.

"I confess that I am still very sad," wrote Touré. "I'm suffering because I feel I have done nothing useful for him the last few weeks. At the end of the season, I wanted to stay for four or five days with my brother before I flew to prepare for the World Cup with Ivory Coast. Except that City did not want to give me a few days. I went to celebrate the title championship in Abu Dhabi while my brother was in his sickbed. By fortune, Kolo was at his bedside."

In the wake of City's trip to Abnu Dhabi, Touré was widely criticised and ridiculed when his agent, Dimitri Seluk, suggested the player might leave the club because they had not shown him enough respect on the occasion of his birthday. At the time Touré confirmed what his agent said was true and said he would explain all in an interview after the World Cup. Following the death of his brother, however, he appears to have used his column to give his side of the story.

"After that I blame myself for not insisting and for not leading them to respect me," he continued. "However, club officials knew that I had been suffering for a few months seeing the health of my brother decline. This is the reason I had several injuries at the end of the season. Because my head had taken control of my body. These last four months have probably been the hardest in my life. I have had sporting success, except that when you get home and you find yourself facing the distress of someone you love, but you do not know how you can help, it's not good."

The Manchester Evening News reports that it is believed Touré didn't specifically request compassionate leave from City to be at his brother's bedside and points out that the club has a good record of accommodating players suffering from off-field problems.

11.26am BST

And this week's Mexican hero is ...

Having stolen the plaudits for his heroic display against Brazil last week, Mexican goalkeeper Guillermo Ochoa has been usurped by his manager Miguel Herrera in the national (and internet) treasure stakes, as Paul Campbell explains.

11.19am BST

Talking points from yesterday

Brazilian schadenfreude, Concacaf's rise, the influence of Fernandinho, a wake-up call for Chile and the Netherlands' strength in depth all feature in our talking points from yesterday's matches. Click on this link to find out more.

10.57am BST

Fifa's guide to England

In their bid to keep viewers of FifaTV informed of the background stories of various nations at World Cup 2014, the good people at world football's governing body have unearthed the curious tale of a tightrope-walking dog from Norwich.Sepp and his cronies take a lot of much-deserved criticism, but they deserve credit for this.

10.51am BST

Want to see some Algeria fans get very excited indeed while watching their country's footballers beat South Korea? Of course you do.

10.44am BST

10.43am BST

An email from Mandy: "Seven men for ITV, six men and a single woman for BBC," she writes. "Football is wonderfully colour-blind these days but can they really not improve on the level of female representation?"

Our own Hadley Freeman addressed this very subject with ITV's controller of sport, Niall Sloane, in her excellent fly-on-the-wall feature on World Cup coverage being provided by ITV and the BBC, prompted by her visits to their respective studios.

"Speaking of relationships, does he think there might ever be a woman on the panel?" she wrote. "He blinks before answering: 'Depends how big the team is. I don’t think you could replace any of the pundits – maybe you could replace me! Certainly some of the most knowledgeable football fans I know are women. But there are only so many seats round the table and you wouldn’t drop any of the pundits. WHOA!'

"When I ask Sloane about the lack of women, he says they’d 'consider' having a female pundit. The BBC later answer this question a little better, saying that they want pundits who have had experience in the sport, and this being men’s football, that means men. But it’s still ridiculous, of course, that neither ITV nor BBC have any female commentators for the whole of their World Cup coverage. But then, I am the only woman from the whole of Fleet Street who was sent out to Brazil so it’s not like TV is the only one with a gender bias when it comes to sport."

10.35am BST

10.32am BST

In praise of Carlos Queiroz

Sir Alex Ferguson’s former assistant admits international sanctions and a lack of starsplay into his conservative instincts, writes Jonathan Wilson. Click on this link to read more.

10.23am BST

10.22am BST

10.18am BST

An email from David Wall: "Quite a bit of the post-mortem of England's first game and the subsequent exit from the tournament has focused on their difficulty in stopping Pirlo influencing that game in contrast to the way that Costa Rica succeeded in doing that," he writes. "I thought Tim Vickery on the radio last night made the most sensible comment about this so far, that it's probably quite significant Costa Rica were playing Italy in the mid-afternoon heat of North-East Brazil just a few days after the 35 year old had had a hard game in the middle of a tropical jungle.

"And watching the match, Pirlo and most of the Italians looked knackered, even misplacing easy short passes to unmarked colleagues, and either not making runs or making runs that were lazy and easy to catch off-side. How much do you think that luck with conditions in various matches has influenced the results so far as many of the teams playing in harder conditions, and at earlier kick-off times, have seemed to struggle in their second matches even if they did well in the first (Germany, for example, looked physically and mentally shaken more easily than you'd expect when Ghana even slightly began to raise the tempo of their match in the second half)?"

10.16am BST

Nazi invasion prompts investigation by Fifa

Fifa’s disciplinary committee are investigating a pitch invasion by a man sporting Nazi daubings during the Germany against Ghana game on Saturday, writes Jonathan. The spectator was escorted off by Ghana’s Sulley Muntari but not before he had removed his shirt and displayed a chest painted with HH for “Heil Hitler”. Commentators have linked this to other apparently racist acts by German fans, including two supporters who blacked their faces and scrawled Ghana on their T-shirts. Germany supporters are sure to come under closer scrutiny for the rest of the tournament.

10.14am BST

Gerrard and Jagielka capped for Hapless XI

Steven Gerrard and Phil Jagielka have been selected in a World Cup Hapless XI by one of Brazil’s sports’ writers, writes Jonathan Watts in his Brazil diary. The England pair – who will probably want to forget their performances against Uruguay – join Brazil’s Fred and Paulinho, as well as Spain’s unfortunate goalkeeper Iker Casillas, in a lineup of misfits and mishits from the second round of group matches chosen by Bernardo Pombo of Globo. He also drew up a Galactico 11 of the best performers, including the Uruguay striker Luis Suárez, whose two goals sunk England, and the Mexico keeper Guillermo Ochoa.

10.05am BST

Australia fans react to their latest defeat

They may have lost three games and shipped nine goals in the process, but Australia's footballers will leave Brazil with their heads held reasonably high. Here's how their supporters reacted in the wake of yesterday's reverse at the hands of Spain.

9.56am BST

When World Cup title defences go bad

With Spain on their way home from Brazil after the group stages, Scott Murray has decided to riff on their pain by looking at five other defending champions who messed up.

9.49am BST

Good morning (BST) everybody. With 36 matches played and just 26 to go, the World Cup is almost over. This Friday, there are no World Cup matches scheduled. The following Wednesday and Thursday? Nothing. It's important, therefore, to watch as much football as is humanly possible in the meantime. Even those matches featuring England and Greece. Today's games ...

  • Italy v Uruguay (Natal 5pm/BST)
  • Costa Rica v England (Belo Horizonte 5pm/BST)
  • Japan v Colombia (Cuiabá 9pm/BST)
  • Greece v Ivory Coast (Fortaleza 9pm)

Updated at 9.50am BST

9.35am BST

Barry Glendenning is your man for the next couple of hours or so. Ta for reading. Bye!

9.33am BST

It didn't always used to be like this. Here's Denis Law sporting an excellent kilt on the way to the airport to be a pundit at the 1978 World Cup in Argentina.

9.27am BST

Also … the state of him.

That said, I've been impressed with Chiles's presenting in Brazil.

Updated at 9.32am BST

9.22am BST

Who would win in a BBC v ITV five-a-side?

Think it's a comfortable victory for the Beeb, especially with the fact that they have Zinedine Kilbane coming off the bench and that ITV have replaced Roy Keane with Clarke Carlisle.

Updated at 9.25am BST

9.01am BST

Morning rumours are up and a World Cup pundit is on his way to QPR, apparently. (Disclaimer: it's not Gordon Strachan, although it would be interesting to know how many of BBC's/ITV's team Harry Redknapp would have at Loftus Road. Definitely Thierry Henry and Clarence Seedorf, and probably still Fabio Cannavaro, Danny Murphy, Alan Shearer and Patrick Vieira to be honest. P Nev as assistant?)

8.51am BST

While we're on Spain, in case you haven't seen this:

Spain’s World Cup ended in recrimination and accusation when the full-back Jordi Alba confronted a journalist and told him: “I’ll rip your head off.”

As he was leaving the Arena da Baixada after the 3-0 win over Australia through the mixed zone where journalists gather to speak to players, Alba passed in front of Javier Gómez Matallanas, a reporter for the sports daily AS. Without stopping he said: “Next time I’ll rip your head off.”

Matallanas expressed his surprise to which Alba added: “Yes, yes, next time … I’m warning you.”

Read the full news story here.


I wouldn't have backed Jordi Alba in a scrap but that's fighting talk. Think Baines could still have him though.

8.43am BST

Can we please have a round of applause for David Villa? 59 goals in 97 appearances – the man is a ruddy legend – he most likely played his last game for Spain yesterday against Australia, signing off with a backheeled goal, of course.

But wait! It's not over!

"I've always said that I love playing in the national team and that's what I've always dreamed of. I would play until I'm 55 but I'm aware that's impossible. I've taken the decision to go to MLS and, as such, I will be without any competitive matches for several months which makes it difficult to continue. Then, after these six months, we'll see. If the coach wants to call me up, I would be delighted."

Ok, it's probably over, but it would be nice for him to get to 100 caps though, yeah?

8.32am BST

Got cake?

Seriously, they must have a wall-chart at the Etihad for the birthdays these days. Must be stressful.

8.26am BST

Choosing your second team is tricky. You can't go all out and pick someone really good, but you probably want someone that is going to make it out of the groups. And picking your team purely based upon how much you like their kit is absolutely fine (RIP Croatia).

While England had a chance to support England in this year's tournament for about five minutes, some nations never got the chance at all. Remember Euro 2008? Kind of like that. We've done a run down of who everyone has been supporting in Afghanistan, Sweden and China, among others, so click here if you're interested.

Updated at 8.26am BST

8.14am BST

Happy Tuesday everyone!

Updated at 8.14am BST

7.43am BST

Exciting times as Ivory Coast prepare to take on Greece, who have now scored two goals in their last 864 World Cup appearances. Will Didier Drogba play though? The Ivory Coast coach Sabri Lamouchi is being very coy: "The difference between you and me is that I know what I will do," Lamouchi said. Nonsense, Sabri. I know exactly what I'm going to do. I'm going to do this: /////////////////////////////////////. Ha! And you can't stop me.

7.37am BST

Argentina's president, Cristina Fernandez, has decided to bring up a cheap World Cup analogy to defende her position in government. "The truth is ... given we're in a World Cup mood, they shoot penalties at me, free kicks, they score with their hand ... The referees screw us over two-thirds of the time with terrible bias."

7.04am BST

Happy birthday Lionel Messi! He's 27 today, and shares his birthday with [frantic googling] Stuart Broad, Vernon Philander, the dude who played RoboCop, fellow football genius Kevin Nolan. Interestingly, Jackie Gleason died on exactly the same day Messi was born, suggesting the little scamp is the reincarnation of the American actor. Oh, and while Messi may have given us the odd goal or two, he also shares his birthday with a man who has contributed much more to world happiness. The man who brought us this. Glenn Medeiros, happy 43rd:

6.51am BST

Chile v Brazil is already looking good enough for a semi-final, let alone a last 16 match. So how are the teams approaching this weekend's game? "Cautiously" sums it up. Here's Luiz Felipe Scolari:

If I could choose I would have picked someone else as Chile are a good South American team, they have quality, they are organised they have the will to succeed. I will look at things when all the adrenaline has left our bodies, sometimes when we look at the match again in the cold light of day we see it in a different way

6.30am BST

Louis van Gaal reckons he'll change his tactics depending on his opponents as the World Cup progresses. Next up for the Dutch are Mexico, who have looked pretty good in the tournament so far and made short work of Croatia last night. Here's Van Gaal:

We limited Chile to a handful of opportunities, we neutralised them extremely effectively. We did have to change our style - and I will always pick a system and a strategy that will help us win.
However, we're not perfect - in possession we still need to improve, but I do think we're very good without the ball

6.00am BST

Good morning/afternoon. So, that's the last we'll see of Spain at this World Cup. But Jordi Alba wasn't going quietly, oh no. As he was leaving the stadium following Spain's win over Australia he told a journalist from AS: "I'll rip your head off". For the good of humanity, Alba didn't follow up on his threat but he did continue the argument later calling the journalist in question, Javier Gómez Matallanas, "a grass". Apparently, Matallanas had told Vicente del Bosque that Andres Iniesta had stolen Fernando Torres's calculator when everyone knows that can't have been true because he was chemistry at the time and that's on the other side of the school from the geography classroom and anyway everyone knows that Matallanas just said that because Iniesta stole his girlfriend last year on the school trip to the train museum and didn't share any of his sweets on the coach back. So there.

  • Email paul.doyle@theguardian.com with your thoughts

safeFields.trailText: Rolling report: Join Jacob Steinberg for all the latest news, updates and results from SW19
safeFields.headline: Wimbledon 2014: day two – live!
safeFields.body:
12.13pm BST

Elsewhere Santiago Giraldo takes the first set of his match against Daniel Gimeno-Traver 6-1. The Colombian is clearly in a hurry - he's got to prepare for his country's World Cup match against Japan tonight. Where's good to buy face paint in Wimbledon village? And does anyone have a Colombian flag going spare?

Updated at 12.14pm BST

12.12pm BST

Hewitt is quickly followed by Wawrinka, who's unflustered against Joao Sousa. An ace brings up set point. Another seals it to the tune of 6-3. The Swiss can see the second round from here.

12.10pm BST

And Lleyton Hewitt is serving for the first set. He makes hard work of it, his Polish foe dragging him to 30-all. "Let's go Lleyton, let's go," the Aussies shout, not specifiying where Lleyton is meant to go. A return from Przysiezny is called out, but a challenge reveals it was in. Replay the point is the cry from the umpire! So they do. And this time Przysiezny sends a slice long, handing Hewitt a set point, which he takes by running round a forehand and whipping it down the line. Cue much fist-pumping and come-onning. You have to admire how much Hewitt loves to win. He takes the first set 6-2 - and in fact, it's the first set of the day. An achievement.

12.05pm BST

There's the breakthrough for Wawrinka. It was coming. He leads 4-2.

11.59am BST

As ever, there'll be a large Japanese contingent here to follow the fortunes of Kei Nishikori. He's taking on the big-serving Frenchman, Kenny de Schepper on Court 12 and Nishikori's adoring fans will like what they're seeing: he's broken already and leads 2-1. Meanwhile it's not looking great for another French contender, Alize Cornet. She's down 3-0 early on against Anna Schmiedlova on Court 19.

11.52am BST

That said, Hewitt is rocking and rolling against poor Przysiezny. He's broken him again and leads 3-0. Aussie! Aussie! Aussie! Oi! Oi! Oi! After victories for banter's Marinko Matosevic and Bernard Tomic yesterday, things are looking up.

11.50am BST

Over on Court 3, the 2002 champion, Lleyton Hewitt, has made a fast start. He's already up a break against Poland's Michal Przysiezny. Now there's a mouthful. I had to squint hard when I was checking out how to spell that surname. Could Hewitt made a challenge this year? Could he party like it's 2002 all over again? No. Let's nip that one in the bud now. Sorry to all the Aussie fans out there, but I fear it will be an early exit for Hewitt. Maybe not today, but it's hard to see him going deep.

11.44am BST

Ladies and gentlemen, I give you Wimbledon: day two. Fans are in seats, some of them even located on a court and not in the champagne bar, umpires are in chairs, players are in action and balls are fizzing across the net. Let's do this. All systems are go. Nothing particularly sensational occurring just yet, but it's early days, there's plenty of time for this to get cooking.

11.38am BST

It's gone 11.30 and players are walking out on court. They'll be playing tennis soon. I'll have my attention trained on Stanislas Wawrinka for the next hour or so. He's struggled since winning in Australia, but could he be a threat to the big guns this year? Well, he's never made much of an impression on grass and was chucked out in the first round by Lleyton Hewitt last year, while he was pulverised by Grigor Dmitrov at Queen's. Stan has a lot to do if he's going to be the man he was in Melbourne.

11.34am BST

I've just spotted Judy Murray outside Centre Court. She was striding along quite purposefully. Not sure where she was heading, but she was heading somewhere, there can be no doubt about that. Stay tuned for further updates.

11.33am BST

The attendance yesterday was down 390 from last year. Is Wimbledon in crisis?

10.41am BST

Preamble

Good morning. The sun was beating down in SW19 yesterday but it was a breeze for Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic in their first-round matches, so, without further ado, over to you, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal. Wimbledon hasn't been kind to them recently. Two years ago, there was the shock of seeing Nadal limp out in the second round to the the unheralded Lukas Rosol, who blasted him off Centre Court under the roof in a bravura performance late on a Thursday night, and the Spaniard didn't even get the past first round last year, losing in meek fashion to Steve Darcis, so who knows what to expect this time? The irrepressible force of nature who roared to yet another French Open or the under-powered version whose knees can't handle the slick grass against players he'd normally expect to swat away in his sleep? We'll find out soon enough. The muscles from Mallorca is on second on Centre Court against Slovakia's Martin Klizan, who will hope to pose him a question or two.

For Federer, there's the ignominy of a spot on Court 1 against Paolo Lorenzi. Again, it's hard to know what to expect from the seven-time champion. He went one better than Nadal last year but was stunned by Sergiy Stakhovsky in the second round and recently lost in the fourth round of the French Open to Ernests Gulbis. But he likes grass. He likes it a lot. If it was legal to do so, you get the feeling Federer would marry grass, have little grass twins with it, live in a house made out of grass. But it's not legal to do that, so he hasn't, he's settled for winning a lot of trophies on it instead. Who wouldn't love to see Federer roll back the years one last time?

He'll have to wait for Jo-Wilfried Tsonga to finish his match against Jurgen Melzer, who's hopefully feeling better than he was yesterday. What an enigma Tsonga is. He raced into a 5-0 lead after 15 minutes yesterday and had the first set wrapped up after 23, but then came the inevitable dip, the loss of the next two sets to a re-energised Melzer, Tsonga's erratic nature plaguing him again. The problem is not even he knows whether what's going to fly off his racquet will be a work of art or a piece of tennis vandalism. But he recovered sufficiently to win the fourth and was serving for the match at 5-4 in the fifth when the heavens opened. So he finds himself in the curious position of having to return this afternoon to win four more points to win the second round.

Elsewhere we have Stanislas Wawrinka, the Australian Open champion, in action against Portugal's Joao Sousa, Milos Raonic against Matthew Ebden and Richard Gasquet against James Duckworth.

We've also got two women's matches on Centre Court. Last year's runner-up, Sabine Lisicki, has hopefully wiped away the tears that flowed down her face during her defeat in the final to Marion Bartoli. The super-smiley German with the huge serve and the pounding groundstrokes is first up against Israel's Julia Glushko, while Serena Williams, who lost to Lisicki last year, is on third against her fellow American, Anna Tatishvili, who shouldn't delay her too long. Will Serena regain her title? She could. But the challengers are lining up.

Chief among them is Maria Sharapova, the 2004 champion. Having won the French Open, she will be in an airy mood and - sorry to say so - the Russian will expect to cruise past Britain's Samantha Murray on Court 1. Then there's the sublimely gifted Eugenie Bouchard, last on Court 1 against Daniela Hanutchova. The Canadian has some skill. She's one to watch. Could go far. Mark my words.

And finally, Heather Watson is in action against the unseeded Croatian, Ajla Tomljanovic. After various British disappointments yesterday, we could do with some PATRIOTIC PRIDE from Watson, who has been making great strides this year after a difficult spell.

Play begins at: 11.30am on the outside courts, 1pm on the show courts.

Updated at 11.12am BST

  • Kevin Mitchell: Nadal and Federer looking good

supporting.trailText: Wimbledon: Andy Murray's title defence is up and running after a 6-1, 6-4, 7-5 win over David Goffin on Centre Court

safeFields.trailText: Andy Murray beat the Belgian David Goffin 6-1, 6-4, 7-5 on Centre Court to begin his defence of the men’s singles title comfortably
safeFields.headline: Andy Murray begins Wimbledon defence with victory over David Goffin
safeFields.body:
So, only six matches to go and Andy Murray will be able to put himself through the torment of creating more tennis history at Wimbledon. Whatever his downbeat demeanour and whatever the pressure heaped on him by an expectant nation, he would not have it any other way.

The Scot began his defence of the title he won in such angst-riddled manner against Novak Djokovic a year ago with a largely untroubled 6-1, 6-4, 7-5 win over the elegant but underpowered and inconsistent Belgian David Goffin on Centre Court on Monday. It could hardly have gone more smoothly.

It took Murray a tick over two hours, less than he might have spent practising for it, to put away the world No105, and he hit his 28 clean winners with encouraging freedom and precision. There was no hint of discomfort from his back, which now seems to have just about healed after surgery nine months ago.

He struck eight aces, the last of them finishing the match, before he cast a quick glance towards his box where his new coach, Amélie Mauresmo, looked down approvingly. She might prove to be an inspired choice, although quite what the 1977 champion, Virginia Wade, thought of it was more than likely of little interest to the Murray camp.

The player and his advisers – including Mauresmo possibly, although she will not be drawn on the subject – were not best pleased with Wade’s gratuitous observation at the weekend that the Frenchwoman was “a little fragile mentally”. Even if that were a valid observation of some of Mauresmo’s playing career, especially when playing in front of her home audience, Murray offered a ringing counterpoint when he said it was just such experiences that would make her the right person to advise him, having gone through all those frustrations and doubts.

It is not as if it is a crime to suffer in sport. Failing and having doubts, as Rafael Nadal has pointed out many times after losing, are part of life. Murray knows, too, that he does not live in some perfect bubble.

Still, he was happy and maybe a bit relieved to get that first match out of the way. It will settle his nerves for bigger challenges to come, even if he is unlikely to meet much stiffer resistance in the second round on Wednesday, when he meets Blaz Rola, a left-handed Slovenian of modest accomplishments and glorious moniker. Rola beat the Spaniard Pablo Andújar 6-3, 6-1, 6-4 in 101 minutes, clearly going for his shots, with 35 winners and 35 unforced errors. He also hit four aces and four double-faults. That is revealing symmetry. This is not a man of half-measures.

The 23-year-old Rola comes from the modern mould: 6ft 4in and 175lb of lean power. He is ranked 92 in the world and spent his formative years in the American college system.

He beat Britain’s Daniel Smethurst (on court here on Tuesday against the American John Isner) in qualifying at Eastbourne last week, having lost to James Ward in straight sets at Queen’s and beaten the Londoner in the French Open.

But Rola comes with baggage, too, having retired with a knee injury when trailing 2-6, 1-3 in the first round against the Argentinian Carlos Berlocq at Eastbourne. If he is in any way fragile – mentally or physically – Murray will find him out on grass that is still fresh and tricky.

As for Murray’s state of mind, he seems just fine. For all the nonsense that swirls about him, he has learned the art of compartmentalising the various strands of his life. When asked on Monday about his recent stint as editor of the Beano, he pointed out: “Those are the sort of things that come up around this time of year for me.”

The 27-year-old champion was relaxed enough to elaborate: “That was a magazine that I read a lot when I was a kid. I was a bit like Dennis [the Menace] probably. I wasn’t particularly well behaved when I was a kid. My mum would definitely say that.”

Well, he was pretty well behaved despatching Goffin who looks young enough to be still reading the Beano. From the moment Murray broke him in the second game of the match until he saved two break points towards the end of the third set, he was in command. It was an efficient, cool performance.

For Goffin, his debut on Centre Court cannot have been that pleasant, given he often put himself into promising positions only to waste the opportunities because of his inability to adjust to the skidding ball on the slick grass.

With groundstrokes looser than Wade’s tongue, Goffin struggled to maintain a rally worth the name in the first 12 minutes, which is when 10 of his 28 unforced errors arrived, and that was way too much of a start to give a player as ruthless as the defending champion.
safeFields.standfirst:
• Champion beats Belgian on Centre Court 6-1, 6-4, 7-5
• Murray faces Slovenia’s Blaz Rola in second round

safeFields.trailText: The Australian Aaron Finch hit 110 in Yorkshire’s 422 to build a 194-run first-innings lead over Warwickshire at Edgbaston
safeFields.headline: Aaron Finch’s century gives Yorkshire dominance over Warwickshire
safeFields.body:
The Australian Aaron Finch struck only the third first-class hundred of his career to boost his Test claims and manoeuvre the joint County Championship leaders Yorkshire into a dominant position at Edgbaston, as they made 422 in reply to Warwickshire’s 228.

Finch snubbed better financial offers from around the shires to join Yorkshire as they promised him championship exposure during the New Zealander Kane Williamson’s absence. The 27-year-old wants to build a case for inclusion on next summer’s Ashes tour but arrived here with poor pedigree in red ball cricket.

An average of just 27 does an injustice to his ability. Although he possesses the hands of a woodcutter not a surgeon, there are few better ball strikers around the globe as his No1 international Twenty20 ranking testifies and two significant changes to his game since he arrived from the Indian Premier League last month appear to have been beneficial.

A tightening of his technique and a drop down the order from the opening spot he occupied for Victoria before being axed from their Sheffield Shield team last winter have seen an improvement in results. He was dismissed for nought in that final match of 2013-14 as New South Wales reduced their opponents to nine for six, but he views his future as a middle-order player, and came into this contest with scores of 34, 63, 45 and three behind him.

Here, he moved up another level to significantly develop the advantage the away side held after arriving at the crease at 150 for four, just 78 runs shy of Warwickshire’s first-innings effort. By lunch the deficit was in the teens with Finch already showing his penchant for launching the ball aerially. Having survived a sharp chance to short leg off Jeetan Patel on 24, he deposited the New Zealand spinner for a straight six on the eve of the interval.

His third six, a thump over extra-cover off the left-armer Keith Barker, landed 17 rows back in the recently built West Stand, during the over in which he celebrated three figures with a gladiatorial swish of his bat and kiss of the Yorkshire emblem. It came during his second significant stand of the innings. Having put on 92 with Jonny Bairstow, he then shared a 123-run alliance with Richard Pyrah.

“It’s a great place to be a part of and I am very grateful for the opportunity to play some four-day cricket,” said Finch. “I have been given it on the back of a couple of very poor seasons for Victoria, and hopefully I can keep scoring runs.

“My technique has changed slightly for the better. They might be very minor changes but they seem to have made a big difference. Over the last 12 months I have played a lot of one-day and Twenty20 cricket and you fall into some movement patterns – because the ball doesn’t move off the seam as significantly or for as long – across your crease to create scoring opportunities on both sides of the wicket.

“It is about getting back to basics and looking down the ground a bit more often and that seems to be working at the moment. I feel like I am in control, not falling over, playing straight, a lot more balanced and in a better position.”

Finch has been called back for a Cricket Australia camp at the end of July although Yorkshire, who signed him on the recommendation of Australia’s coach, Darren Lehmann, are considering making a request for special dispensation.

Warwickshire finally snared him for 110 when the wicketkeeper Tim Ambrose hauled down a top-edged pull at full stretch. In fact, cross-bat shots were a feature of several Yorkshire dismissals: captain Andrew Gale skied a Chris Wright bumper while Bairstow played on pulling at Boyd Rankin and Ryan Sidebottom swished fatally outside off stump.

Any chance of Warwickshire wresting the momentum went during an awful opening to the second morning when, with Chris Woakes surprisingly overlooked, Rankin and Wright served up seven boundaries in the first 19 deliveries.
